SENT.plain: OBJECTIVE: To determine the association between 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25-OHD) concentration and risk of incident type 2 diabetes

RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS: In a nested case-control study conducted among 608 women with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes and 559 control subjects in the Nurses' Health Study, we measured the association between baseline plasma 25-OHD concentration and risk of incident diabetes
RESULTS: After adjusting for matching factors and diabetes risk factors, including BMI, higher levels of plasma 25-OHD were associated with a lower risk for type 2 diabetes
The odds ratio for incident type 2 diabetes in the top (median 25-OHD, 33.4 ng/ml) versus the bottom (median 25-OHD, 14.4 ng/ml) quartile was 0.52 (95% CI 0.33-0.83)
The associations were consistent across subgroups of baseline BMI, age, and calcium intake
CONCLUSIONS: Plasma 25-OHD concentration was associated with lower risk of incident type 2 diabetes in women
